_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EPA RMP Executive Summary
Chemical Research & Licensing (CR&L) conducts research and utilizes pilot plants to develop process technologies used by the refining and petrochemical industry.  CR&L's SIC code is 8731 (NAICS 541712).

CR&L is committed to protection of the health and safety of people in our workplace, the public and the environment.  We believe occupational illnesses, injuries and environmental incidents are preventable, and their occurrence is unacceptable.  CR&L's objective is to continuously improve health, safety and environmental (HSE) performance and be a recognized leader in industry.  

CR&L's policy is to:
A?    Operate facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state and local regulations
A?    Consider HSE implications during product development, testing, processing and storage
A?    Devote sufficient resources to be viewed as an industry leader in the area of HSE performance

Risk management (i.e. identifying and managing hazards and potentially adverse effects of activities on people, the environment, assets or reputation) is a vital part of CR&L's HSE program.  CR&L uses a HSE management system to define and manage risks at the site, and ensure operations are in compliance with applicable laws and regulations.  The management system has four basic components:
A?    Identification
A?    Assessment
A?    Provision of controls
A?    Recovery preparedness
Assessment of risks and hazards considers the full life cycle of an activity from beginning to end.  All steps are documented.

Hazard Assessment

CR&L's hazard assessment process : 
A?    Identifies HSE hazards and potentially adverse effects, and assesses related risks which could arise from existing or proposed activities which could potentially affect the:
o    Health and safety of employees, contractors or the public
o    Environment, including soil and groundwater contamination
o    Company's reputation, liabilities or profitability
o    Company's assets
A?    Uses risk assessment methodologies, including scenarios and

consequences/probability ratings (Risk Assessment Matrix) appropriate for the hazard, effect and associated risk(s) being considered.
A?    Applies, as a function of the risk level, appropriate controls to prevent, or reduce likelihood of, occurrence, and applies appropriate recovery measures to reduce the possible effects of HSE risks
A?    Assures measures for risk control and recovery are adequate and clearly linked to related tasks/activities (competence/responsibility) assigned to specific individuals in the organization
A?    Manages changes to facilities, processes, operations and other activities to assure hazards, effects and risks are reassessed and plans for HSE event prevention, control and recovery are updated accordingly
A?    Applies Product Stewardship as part of a HSE effort that manages hazards and effects during all phases of the life cycle of our products.


Worst-Case Scenario:
Isobutane (CAS 75-28-5) in transport tanker truck
Vapor cloud explosion
Instantaneous and simultaneous failure of inner and outer tank walls
Failure of all active safety systems
Worst-case weather conditions (stable, low wind speed)
Total release - entire vessel contents of 32115 pounds
Endpoint of release - 1 PSI overpressure
Area impacted:  0.3 miles (1584 feet)

Alternative Release Scenario:
Isobutane (CAS 75-28-5) in transport tanker truck
Vapor cloud explosion
Failure of a pressure relief valve on loading tanker truck
No active and passive safety systems workings
Most common weather conditions
Release rate:  3770 pounds per minute
Total release time:  8.52 minutes
Area impacted:  0.1 miles (528 feet)


Five-Year Accident History:
CR&L has had no reportable releases of toxic or flammable substances in the past five years.

Accident Prevention Program

A?    Storage vessels are high-pressure construction; pressure relieves to flare
A?    High flow shutoff valves on LPG trailers and isotainers
A?    Emergency equipment shutdown procedures
A?    Water fog used to mitigate releases
A?    Regulator

y guidelines for safe operation (OSHA PSM and EPA RMP)
A?    Risk management program
A?    Mechanical integrity program
A?    Employee training
A?    Process hazard analyses
A?    Management of change
A?    Policies and procedures for safe operation of equipment

Emergency Response Program

 CR&L's emergency response program is comprehensive, providing:
A?    public notification through the CAER Line
A?    emergency medical treatment through arrangements with local clinics and hospitals
A?    emergency response procedures 
A?    plan coordination with the community through the Southeast Regional LEPC
A?    prompt response to requests for additional information from local officials

CR&L's plan is regularly evaluated and updated as needed.  All alarms are audible and can be automatically or manually activated.  Personnel are trained to isolate the point of release, coordinate response activities with third party responders and activate the CAER line as necessary.

Emergency response systems include:
A?    Audible alarm systems for notification of personnel and neighboring facilities, including paging horns, fire alarms, and high and low gas detection alarms.
A?    Mobile fire protection equipment (portable 20 pound and wheeled 50 pound fire extinguishers)
A?    Water fog for minimization of the effect of releases by knocking down vapors and cooling tanks
A?    Communication link to off-site responders
A?    CAER Line system to notify public and neighboring facilities of emergencies and actions to be taken
